text: yeah yeah hi everyone Anthony Fantana
here the Internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
scissor record Z kal what what do you
what do you think of scissor I WA
she gobbles and she look pretty as hell
everything is the same nothing at all is
different right nothing is completely
different everything is as it should be
that's right also before we go into this
review I want to say that the views
expressed in this review are are my own
and not count Church Estes scissor
recent TDE signee
as well as a singer-songwriter you might
have heard her make a few vocal
appearances lately on her own stuff like
the EPS that she's dropped one that came
out last year as well as some
appearances on the latest Isaiah Rashad
project or on schoolboy Q's latest LP
but personally I wasn't really excited
for whatever she was going to come out
with this year until I heard one of the
lead tracks from it babylon before a
kendrick lamar feature was thrown on top
of it which is actually pretty
unfortunate I feel weird saying this but
the song was perfectly fine without
Kendrick Lamar and with how he dominates
the track on this new version and it's
almost like the track is a Kendrick
Lamar song that says is merely just
featured on but the original version of
this track was wonderful atmospheric it
was sensual it was a really pretty piece
of reverb dand cavernous R&B and neo
soul it was a track that seemed like it
was as indebted to Badu as it was to
Bjork scissors vocals felt dramatic they
felt weary on this track I loved some of
the lyrics on this thing to like bring
the thorny crown crucify me I also love
the way the lumbering beat on this track
moved felt trap influenced but yet some
of the heavy grooves felt like they
could have come out of a dubstep track
or something but at least that influence
felt very very very subtle didn't
overtake the track or anything like that
it was just a great song the last thing
it needed was a wrap
verse even from a good rapper so with my
favorite track on this LP before I even
listen to this LP being completely
gutted and mortally wounded I was kind
of worried as to how I would manage to
enjoy the rest of this record I was
wondering how the rest of this LP would
fare and not well I don't think in my
opinion siz it was totally bold on the
song Babylon and and I think it's the
opposite on the rest of this thing the
opener you are maybe the the sleepiest
start to a record I've heard this year a
song is way too hypnotized by its own
slow pace an atmosphere to come together
with a memorable tune this song to me
isn't really much more than than a vibe
or a feeling or the the semblance of a
song but I don't even really think it
does a good job of holding its serene
feelings since the really heavy rough
jutting baseline bouncing all over this
track makes sure that that doesn't
happen then there's the song child's
play which uses a really stale old xx YY
xxp which is good for him but a lot of
people have already heard this beat up
until this point Milo rapped on it a few
years ago and Sousa doesn't even really
make sure that this instrumental gets
altered before it hops onto this record
just to give it kind of a new Flair or
even structure it to the point where the
song goes over well I mean cezzah is
singing in the middle of this track and
then all of a sudden chants the rapper's
verse just starts without so much as an
interlude or a break or an introduction
he just simply starts rapping over her
as if she hadn't been singing the entire
time it's like he just steps on her
verse the only guest vocalist on this
entire LP that actually complements
what's going on in the song is Isaiah
Rashad and even though the track he
appears on is off to kind of a shaky
start once it settles in to the moment
where he is featured it really smoothes
out into a very pretty breathy voice
duet I love the chilly synthesizers on
this track I love the Forrest Gump
reference that runs through as they are
singing together and the beat on this
thing and the bassline on this thing it
feels like I'm listening to
Portishead track or something but with a
much stronger aren't be influenced and I
think this track this song this
emulation goes over really well however
there are other spots on here that
sounds similar to other things but
aren't quite as interesting there's the
song Giulio which is an 80s tinged piece
of synthesizer pop where scissors vocals
and the melody of the track are
incredibly nondescript
the nostalgic tone of the
instrumentation is really the most
memorable thing about it and then
there's the song sweet November where I
don't really mind the vocals but the
instrumental on this thing is is is so
shoddy and so badly pulled together it's
it's nearly unlistenable at least to me
it's just a really bad piece of
recreated soul nostalgia where the
guitars are just irritatingly loose and
amateurish I mean listening to the
guitars on this track actually reminded
me of an old MF DOOM line don't touch
the mic like there's aids on it like
don't be afraid to handle the mic wrap
on the mic to me the guitar playing on
this track is essentially playing the
guitar like there's aids on it there are
a few tracks on this thing that really
stand out to me is being likable though
like the song hijack which to me has a
lot of the characteristics that the
original version of Babylon used to the
emotive vocals the atmospheric
production it feels like an R&B slow jam
but it's so much more futuristic there's
a lovely chorus I love the way since pop
in toward the end of the track and
really change up the mood and the vibe
of the song it's not the most original
track I've heard in this more modern
shade of R&B music but it does reach a
level of quality that I wish the low
points of this record did but outside of
that I just feel either underwhelmed or
just incredibly displeased by nearly
every other song on this thing I mean
the song shattered ring what is going on
with the instrumental on this track with
the twangy guitar and the heavy beat it
feels like it would have been a better
fit for like a lot of delray song and
with all the massive walls of synths in
this track I feel like scissors very
breathy vocals don't go over too well
and she is just merely buried under all
of it sometimes I feel like there's more
focus on the bells and the whistles and
the perceived epicness of the
instrumental
then there is on just coming out with a
good song which I thought is what I was
going to get given how great the track
Babylon was originally but I just don't
know I just stare at this album and I
just think what happened with the guests
and the TDE affiliation and the good
songs that I heard previously the fact
that I know that she can sing and on top
of all of that the quality of production
this project could have had I really
feel like Z should have been a layup but
instead it was just like a massive brick
outside of a few songs a vast majority
of this project is just uninteresting
from the tracks where scissors vocal
performances really lack conviction and
emotion to a lot of the moments where
the songs are just underwhelming and
just not that distinct to the other
moments where the instrumentals are
incredibly lacking in terms of good
sounds or just fresh ideas I'm feeling a
strong four to a light five on this
thing transition if you've given this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana scissor forever
